author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Kansas State’s Ayoka Lee Sets Division I Women’s Single-Game Scoring Record
description: Her 61 points propelled the Wildcats to a 94-65 thrashing of No. 14 Oklahoma on Sunday.
content: Kansas State center Ayoka Lee broke a 35-year-old record on Sunday, scoring 61 points, the most in a Division I women’s college basketball game, while leading her team to a 94-65 victory over No. 14 Oklahoma in Manhattan, Kan. She was 5 points short of scoring more than the opposing team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: At Least 6 Killed in Crush at African Cup Match
description: Witnesses said the stadium stewards closed the gates and stopped allowing people in, setting off the crush.
content: YAOUNDÉ, Cameroon — At least six people died in a crush outside a stadium in Cameroon hosting a game in Africa’s top soccer tournament on Monday, a local government official said, realizing fears over the nation’s capacity to stage the continent’s biggest sporting event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Rich Countries Lure Health Workers From Low-Income Nations to Fight Shortages
description: Huge pay incentives and immigration fast-tracks are leading many to leave countries whose health systems urgently need their expertise.
content: LUSAKA, Zambia — There are few nurses in the Zambian capital with the skills and experience of Alex Mulumba, who works in the operating room at a critical care hospital. But he has recently learned, through a barrage of social media posts and LinkedIn solicitations, that many faraway places are eager for his expertise, too — and will pay him far more than the $415 per month (including an $8 health risk bonus) he earns now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Activist Investors Assemble
description: Shareholders are pushing for big changes at Unilever, Peloton and Kohl’s.
content: Unilever has faced pressure on multiple fronts for weeks, including pushback from shareholders over its now-abandoned pursuit of GlaxoSmithKline’s consumer business. Now the consumer goods giant must deal with a potentially bigger headache: Trian Partners, the activist investment firm run by Nelson Peltz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Donna Barba Higuera Wins Newbery Medal for ‘The Last Cuentista’
description: “Watercress,” illustrated by Jason Chin and written by Andrea Wang, won the Caldecott Medal.
content: “The Last Cuentista,” Donna Barba Higuera’s dystopian yet hopeful middle-grade novel, received this year’s John Newbery Medal on Monday, winning one of the most prestigious prizes in children’s literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘The Books of Jacob,’ a Nobel Prize Winner’s Sophisticated and Overwhelming Novel
description: Set in the mid-18th century, Olga Tokarczuk’s enormous novel is about a charismatic self-proclaimed messiah who attracts and repels crowds and authorities in equal measure.
content: The Polish writer Olga Tokarczuk was, in 2019, a youthful winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature. She was 57, dreadlocked, mischievous of politics, a vegetarian.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Yorkers Reel From a Torrent of Sad News and Struggles
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 24, 2022.
content: “I’m afraid because I’m Asian. We don’t go out at night, we don’t take the subway — what can we do? No hope, just living.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 24, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 24, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italians Vote for a President. Here’s Why It Matters.
description: The normally mundane ritual of electing a president every seven years has turned more fateful this year, with Italy’s political stability potentially hanging in the balance.
content: ROME — A joint session of Italian parliament and some regional delegates, known as “great electors,” began a secret ballot on Monday to elect the next Italian president to replace the current office holder, Sergio Mattarella, as the country’s head of state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Military Takes Power in West African Nation of Burkina Faso
description: Mutinous officers said the public was fed up with President Roch Marc Christian Kaboré because of his inability to stop attacks by Islamist militants.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — The military seized power in Burkina Faso on Monday, ousting the country’s democratically elected president after mutinous soldiers stormed his home, in the latest of a series of military coups in African countries struggling to beat back a rising tide of Islamist violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A two-bedroom cottage in Pasadena, a Craftsman bungalow in Oakland and a 1942 ranch house in Napa.
content: This house is a few blocks from the Bungalow Heaven neighborhood, on a wide, tree-lined street where most of the houses date to the 1920s and 1930s. It’s about half a mile from McDonald Park, with its softball diamond, basketball and volleyball courts and children’s playground, and from Marshall Fundamental Secondary School, which enrolls nearly 2,000 students in sixth through 12th grades. Caltech and Pasadena City College are five minutes away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Kansas City loses its standout safety, Tyrann Mathieu, to a concussion.
description: Mathieu is known for infusing the right attitude in the locker room.
content: Kansas City safety Tyrann Mathieu has been ruled out for the rest of the game and is in the concussion protocol, team officials said during the second quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Stowaway Survives Flight to Amsterdam in Wheel Bay of Cargo Plane
description: The police are investigating how a 22-year-old man from Kenya got onto the flight, which took off in Johannesburg and stopped in Nairobi.
content: The Dutch police said that they had found a 22-year-old Kenyan man in the front wheel section of a cargo plane that landed in Amsterdam on Sunday morning after flying from Johannesburg via Nairobi.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen to ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
description: A collection of episodes covering topics as deep as they are broad.
content: With a broad-ranging curiosity, a deep interest in the world and an unusual ability to shape-shift to the topic and discuss it knowledgeably, Ezra Klein brings listeners sharp and unusual takes from experts in everything from antiracism to trauma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Four Attorneys General Claim Google Secretly Tracked People
description: Three states and the District of Columbia allege that the tech giant misled consumers by continuing to track those who had changed their privacy settings to prevent data collection.
content: The District of Columbia and three states sued Google on Monday, claiming that the tech giant deceived consumers to gain access to their location data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: We Used to Care That Football Players Got Concussions
description: We seem to have lost our faith that we can make things better.
content: Of all the disappearing stories in the American consciousness, none has receded from the public eye quite like football concussions. It’s hard to remember now, but less than a decade ago, President Barack Obama said that if he had a son, he would have to think “long and hard” before letting him play football. Stories were published about parents pulling their children from youth and high school football; obituaries were written for the future of the sport. In 2015, Will Smith, one of the biggest movie stars in the world, starred as Dr. Bennet Omalu, the forensic pathologist whose research first linked football with chronic traumatic encephalopathy (C.T.E.), a brain disease that leads to memory loss, erratic behavior and depression. One study found C.T.E. in 110 of 111 deceased N.F.L. players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Sarah Palin, who is unvaccinated, recently dined indoors in New York City before testing positive.
description: Elio’s, an Upper East Side celebrity haunt, confirms that it let her in despite a city requirement that all indoor guests show proof of vaccination. Ms. Palin tested positive for the coronavirus on Monday.
content: Sarah Palin, who is not vaccinated against the coronavirus, dined indoors Saturday night at Elio’s, an Italian restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that regularly draws celebrities, despite New York City’s requirement that all indoor guests show proof of vaccination. She tested positive for the virus on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sayre Quevedo, Annie Brown, Wendy Dorr, Mike Benoist, Corey Schreppel and Marion Lozano
title: Documenting a Death by Euthanasia
description: Belgium has some of the world’s most liberal euthanasia laws. A photojournalist documented a paralympian’s experience of them.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Roles of F.B.I. and Informants Muddle the Michigan Governor Kidnapping Case
description: Before five men stand trial in March, prosecutors and defense lawyers are examining more than 1,000 hours of secretly recorded conversations.
content: On a rainy night in northern Michigan in September 2020, a group of armed men divided among three cars surveyed the landscape around the vacation cottage of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, considering how to kidnap her as payback for her Covid-19 lockdown measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Court Approves Special Grand Jury in Trump Election Inquiry
description: A district attorney in Georgia is investigating possible election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies.
content: A Georgia district attorney’s request to convene a special grand jury was approved Monday in the criminal investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election results in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Everything You Need to Bake a Valentine’s Day Treat
description: Handstand Kitchen offers a new decorating kit with tools and recipes for cookies and cupcakes.
content: Valentines to mail have already filled store racks, so it’s not too soon to think about valentines to bake. Handstand Kitchen offers everything children and adults may need to make and decorate cookies and cupcakes for the holiday. New to the collection this year is a cookie decorating kit with stainless steel cutters, a nonstick baking sheet, spatula, decorating stencils, decorating tools including frosting bags, and recipes. The company also sells heart-shaped molds for cupcakes and candy, spatulas and cookie cutters separately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: James Maraniss, Librettist of Long-Silent Opera, Dies at 76
description: A Spanish scholar who taught for more than four decades at Amherst College, he waited, along with the composer, 32 years for “Life Is a Dream” to be staged.
content: James Maraniss, a Spanish scholar who wrote the libretto for an opera that was finished in 1978, won a Pulitzer Prize in 2000 but was not fully staged for another decade, died on Jan. 9 at his home in Chesterfield, Mass. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: To Hippos, a Wheeze and a Honk Mean More Than Just ‘Hello!’
description: By playing a variety of recordings of “wheeze honks” to pods of hippopotamuses, researchers began to decipher how the animals communicate with one another.
content: Hippopotamuses are some of the most unfriendly creatures in the animal kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: The federal jury in the case is far less diverse than the one that convicted Derek Chauvin of murder.
description: The jurors in Derek Chauvin’s trial came from the Minneapolis area, which is more racially mixed and more liberal than other areas of Minnesota.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — The selection of a jury for the state trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who was convicted last spring of murdering George Floyd, took almost two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Covid setbacks to schooling are ‘nearly insurmountable,’ the U.N. says.
description: Many millions of children have “significantly missed out” on the academic learning they would have acquired in the classroom, the United Nations Children’s Fund said in a new report.
content: Almost two years into the coronavirus pandemic, more than 635 million children globally remain affected by full or partial school closures, the United Nations said Monday in a report that called the setbacks to education “nearly insurmountable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Puts 8,500 Troops on ‘High Alert’ Amid Ukraine Tensions
description: The move signals a shift for the Biden administration as the United States and NATO allies brace for possible Russian military action.
content: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has put 8,500 American troops on “high alert” for possible deployment to Eastern Europe, as NATO and the United States braced for a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Pentagon announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: How Do You Mourn a 250-Year-Old Giant?
description: Protecting trees in public areas is a no-brainer. Protecting them on private land is a far greater challenge.
content: NASHVILLE — Down the street, right after Christmas, a developer knocked down a perfectly good house, along with nearly every tree on the deeply treed lot. It’s an old story here, and the pure waste of it is always appalling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Sheldon Silver, a New York Power Broker Convicted of Corruption, Dies at 77
description: A Democratic leader of the State Assembly, he held sway in New York politics for decades and died while serving a prison sentence.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Sheldon Silver, the once-indomitable leader of the New York State Assembly whose career and reputation were undone by a 2015 corruption conviction, died on Monday. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Gunman Accused of Shooting 2 N.Y.P.D. Officers Dies
description: The Manhattan district attorney is investigating Lashawn McNeil’s connection to anti-government groups; Mayor Eric Adams said an assault weapon was found under his mattress.
content: Lashawn McNeil, the man who the New York City police said shot and killed one officer and critically wounded another in Harlem last week, died on Monday, two police officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Derek Chauvin was convicted of George Floyd’s murder. Could he testify against his fellow officers?
description: Derek Chauvin’s presence will be felt throughout the federal trial of the three officers who were with him when he murdered George Floyd.
content: [Follow live coverage of the civil rights trial against three ex-police officers in the killing of George Floyd.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Democrats in Congress Seek Review of Teams Within the Border Patrol
description: Lawmakers asked the Government Accountability Office to review “critical incident teams,” and two House committees will conduct a separate investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats on Monday called for a review of secretive teams within the U.S. Border Patrol that have multiple roles, including protecting agents against potential civil liability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Steven Erlanger
title: NATO Steps Up Readiness in Eastern Europe to Reassure Allies
description: The alliance is sending more jets and ships to the region. The decision comes as Britain joined the U.S. in withdrawing the families of diplomats in Kyiv.
content: KYIV — NATO said on Monday that some member countries were putting their forces on standby and sending additional ships and fighter jets to Eastern Europe to reassure allies in the region, as Britain joined the United States in ordering families of diplomats out of Ukraine, citing “the growing threat from Russia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raillan Brooks and Jolie Ruben
title: Portrait of the artist: behind our photo of Shane MacGowan of the Pogues.
description: For a recent profile of Shane MacGowan, the former frontman of the Pogues who is known both for his music and his hard living, the photographer Ellius Grace took this striking image at the musician’s home in Dublin. “It was just him testing me to see if I could keep up with him,” Grace recalled of his shoot of MacGowan, who is releasing “The Eternal Buzz and the Crock of Gold,” a new book of artwork, lyrics and essays. “When he gave me a face, I would get close up. That’s when I got the gold teeth.”
content: For a recent profile of Shane MacGowan, the former frontman of the Pogues who is known both for his music and his hard living, the photographer Ellius Grace took this striking image at the musician’s home in Dublin. “It was just him testing me to see if I could keep up with him,” Grace recalled of his shoot of MacGowan, who is releasing “The Eternal Buzz and the Crock of Gold,” a new book of artwork, lyrics and essays. “When he gave me a face, I would get close up. That’s when I got the gold teeth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaevon Williams
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Promised Land’ and a Janet Jackson Special
description: ABC debuts a new drama about a wine-country power struggle. And a four-part documentary about Janet Jackson debuts on Lifetime and A&E.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 24-30. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diante Lee
title: What We Learned in the Divisional Round of the N.F.L. Playoffs
description: Jimmy Garoppolo screened his way back to a conference championship, the Bengals’ defensive front outshone its stars, and only Kansas City benefited from home-field advantage.
content: This weekend’s divisional-round games provided a few surprises, beginning with the top seeds in both conferences getting tossed, Joe Burrow’s being sacked nine times overcoming Ryan Tannehill’s three interceptions and Aaron Rodgers’s earlier-than-predicted consideration of his next team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Sarah Palin Tests Positive, Delaying Libel Case Against The Times
description: Jed S. Rakoff, the judge in the trial, said it would now begin on Feb. 3, after three positive test results for Ms. Palin.
content: Sarah Palin has tested positive for the coronavirus, forcing the delay of her defamation trial against The New York Times until next week. The trial, which was set to begin with jury selection on Monday morning, is now scheduled to start on Feb. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Stephen Sondheim Leaves Rights to His Works to a Trust
description: The trust will determine what happens to the intellectual property of the celebrated lyricist and composer, who died in November.
content: Stephen Sondheim left the rights to all of his work — including his contribution to musicals such as “Sweeney Todd” and “Into the Woods,” as well as any unfinished shows — to a trust that will manage his estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Irish Police Investigate Mysterious Death in Post Office
description: The police said a man was found dead in a post office where pensions were collected. Witnesses told the Irish media that two men had brought him there to collect his funds.
content: DUBLIN — The police in Ireland said on Monday they were investigating an incident in which a man was found dead at his local post office. Witnesses told the Irish media that the older man had been brought in by two men who tried to claim his pension on his behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Ashley Southall
title: Adams Unveils Ambitious Plan to Confront Rising Gun Violence
description: Mayor Eric Adams’s proposal includes the restoration of a controversial anti-gun police unit.
content: Mayor Eric Adams, facing severe pressure to address a growing crisis of gun violence in New York City, announced an ambitious public safety plan on Monday in what has quickly become a pivotal moment in his first weeks in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Hill
title: Putin Has the U.S. Right Where He Wants It
description: Vladimir Putin’s aim is bigger than closing NATO’s “open door” to Ukraine and taking more territory.
content: We knew this was coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: S&P 500, Burkina Faso, Hippos: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Inflation Has Arrived. Here’s What You Need to Know.’
description: U.S. inflation is at a 40-year high. In this lesson, students will learn about why prices rise or fall over time and what it means for the nation.
content: Featured Article: “Inflation Has Arrived. Here’s What You Need to Know.” by Jeanna Smialek
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: In Los Angeles, Veggie Burgers With Real Veggies Still Appeal
description: Synthetic meat imitations are widely available, but our critic still loves a classic plant patty.
content: LOS ANGELES — For every hamburger in this city, there exists an equal but opposite veggie burger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Seven school boards sue Virginia’s governor over his order making masks optional.
description: The filing questions the constitutionality of Gov. Glenn Youngkin’s order allowing parents to decide whether their children should comply with mask rules at school.
content: Seven school districts in Virginia sued Gov. Glenn Youngkin on Monday, objecting to his executive order overruling their mask policies and making the wearing of masks optional in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: The Tao of Wee Man
description: His world was radically altered by “Jackass.” But now, Jason Acuña has harnessed his fame to live the life of his dreams.
content: Some of the earliest hours of my life have been spent with Jason Acuña. The pattern of our days was established at our first meeting: I would contrive to arrive before him to whatever sunrise activity Acuña, better known as Wee Man, had planned for us, and he would already be there, shouting a greeting in his psyched-up Southern California drawl. The first time I was late to being early, he was going to teach me how to skateboard. I found him in the middle of a friendly conversation with a man who appeared to be living in a car. Acuña was giving him some free merchandise from his sock line.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Fall of Afghanistan
description: Listen to a collection of episodes of “The Daily” focusing on voices of Afghans who fear for their lives under Taliban rule.
content: The fall of Afghanistan risked becoming an abstraction. In 2021, “The Daily” refused to let that happen, producing a series of visceral, fly-on-the-wall interviews with Afghans whose lives were at greatest risk as the Taliban closed in and whose chances of escape were rapidly fading. The result is a historical record of the most essential and urgent kind: Afghans, in their own voices, delivering raw testimony about the end of life as they had known it and their rage at the American and coalition forces who had abandoned them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Jonathan Freeman, Jafar in ‘Aladdin,’ Hangs Up His Cobra Staff
description: He voiced the evil sorcerer in the Disney movies, and originated the character in the Broadway production. On Sunday, he took his final bow in the show.
content: He is, as Iago puts it in the classic Disney film, the “all-mighty evil one.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: A Fight Over Rooftop Solar Threatens California’s Climate Goals
description: Utility regulators have proposed slashing the incentives homeowners receive to install solar panels, a long-sought goal of utilities and labor unions.
content: California has led the nation in setting ambitious climate change goals and policies. But the state’s progress is threatened by a nasty fight between rival camps in the energy industry that both consider themselves proponents of renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Will Robots Really Destroy the Future of Work?
description: A new book argues that workers can thrive despite technology that eliminates jobs.
content: Some people on the political right love robots and hate labor unions. Some people on the political left are the opposite: They hate robots and love labor unions. Then there’s David Autor, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He loves both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Top Jan. 6 Investigator Fired From Post at the University of Virginia
description: Democrats in Virginia denounced the action as a partisan move aimed at helping former President Donald J. Trump undercut the investigation of the Capitol riot.
content: The top staff investigator on the House committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol has been fired by the state’s new Republican attorney general from his position as the top lawyer for the University of Virginia, from which he was on leave while working on the congressional inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Judge Lifts Order Preventing Wisconsin Hospital Workers From Starting New Jobs
description: ThedaCare had sought to temporarily prevent seven employees from leaving for jobs at Ascension, saying the departures would jeopardize patient care. A judge sided with the workers on Monday.
content: A judge in Wisconsin on Monday lifted an order that had temporarily blocked seven employees of ThedaCare, a major regional hospital system, from leaving for new jobs with another health care network until it could find people to replace them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Harry Potter and the Cursed Child’ Fires Its Harry Potter
description: The Broadway production dismissed the actor James Snyder, citing unspecified concerns about his conduct after an investigation of a complaint by a castmate.
content: The Broadway production of “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” has fired the actor playing the title character, citing unspecified concerns about his conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Taqueria Ramírez Brings a Mexico City Specialty to Brooklyn
description: A cut of beef little known in the United States emerges from a meat hot tub in Greenpoint to make a smooth, tender taco.
content: Between the ribs of a steer and its skin lies a thin, flat, broad muscle. While more familiar beef cuts are more or less the ruby red of uncooked steak, this one is a pale and milky pink, from which it gets one of its names, “rose meat.” It is also known as the twitch muscle or the fly shaker because, quickly contracted, it will make the cow’s flank shudder, driving away biting insects if the cow is lucky. In the United States, though, there is almost no market for this cut under any name. Most of it goes into burgers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Thierry Mugler, Genre-Busting French Fashion Designer, Dies at 73
description: The dominatrix-loving couturier turned sex into a style weapon.
content: Thierry Mugler, the outrageous, genre-busting French designer who dominated European runways in the late 1980s and early 1990s, died on Sunday at his home in Vincennes, outside Paris. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: ‘Encanto’ Soundtrack Returns to No. 1, Beating Gunna and the Weeknd
description: Disney’s latest animated film is the first since “Frozen” with music topping the Billboard 200 for multiple weeks.
content: When the soundtrack to “Encanto,” Disney’s latest animated film, came out two months ago, it was by no means a hit, entering the Billboard 200 chart at No. 197.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Why Christine Baskets Was One of TV’s Greatest Characters
description: In the FX comedy “Baskets,” Louie Anderson brought humanity to a type of woman who is rarely given her due onscreen.
content: When Louie Anderson died on Friday, it felt like dozens of moms who I knew and loved all died at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: These Mothers Were Exhausted, So They Met on a Field to Scream
description: The pandemic has been relentless for mothers, many of whom have been stuck in an endless cycle of work and child care. Some Massachusetts mothers gathered to do something about it.
content: In Boston, many mothers were exhausted. The pandemic had been so draining that they wanted to scream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: City Ballet Promotes Seven Dancers as Performances Resume
description: A crew of corps de ballet members, six women and one man, head into the delayed winter season with a new rank: soloist.
content: It started out like any other Saturday at New York City Ballet: company class followed by a day of rehearsals. But for seven dancers, it ended better than usual. Preston Chamblee, Ashley Hod, Emily Kikta, Isabella LaFreniere, Miriam Miller, Mira Nadon and Emma Von Enck, all members of the corps de ballet, were promoted to soloist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Side Tables
description: Small but essential, they personalize a room. And you need somewhere to put that cup of coffee.
content: Side tables are among the smallest pieces of furniture, but they make a big difference in the way a room looks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Buried,’ ‘Night Comes On’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Put these off-the-radar movies on your radar.
content: This month’s recommendations for subscription service sleepers include a trio of incisive indie coming-of-age dramas, a pair of stylish but thoughtful action flicks, documentaries for music fans and much more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Grimness of January
description: New York City, already exhausted by the pandemic, is uneasy after a barrage of shootings.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the mood in New York City after three emotionally grueling weeks. We’ll also look at a mural that is leaving Rikers Island after 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Silvana Estrada Arrives With a Devastating Album About Heartbreak
description: The Mexican singer-songwriter’s debut solo album, “Marchita,” paints a tender portrait of lost love, putting her voice and her Venezuelan cuatro center stage.
content: Silvana Estrada is the kind of artist who speaks like she’s writing poetry in real time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Thomas
title: Can a New Line of Work Help Save These Wild Welsh Ponies?
description: A longstanding source of local pride and affection, Welsh mountain ponies have seen many of their traditional roles vanish. A new initiative aims to ensure their continued survival.
content: As a keen equestrian, I felt a little odd to be pulling on hiking shoes, rather than riding boots, as I prepared for a day out with horses. But this wasn’t going to be an ordinary hike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Omicron’s Radical Evolution
description: Thirteen of Omicron’s mutations should have hurt the variant’s chances of survival. Instead, they worked together to make it thrive.
content: As nurses and doctors struggle with a record-breaking wave of Omicron cases, evolutionary biologists are engaged in a struggle of their own: figuring out how this world-dominating variant came to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: There Is Plenty to Learn From an Election, Even if No One Wins
description: David Ortiz could be voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame on Tuesday, but there will be trends worth noting even if he, Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens and others fall short.
content: The vast collection of artifacts at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., includes dozens of items from the careers of Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens. There are bats and helmets used by Bonds, spikes and caps used by Clemens, and much more. Those players are essential to the history of baseball, and the hallowed museum tells their stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Cruise Has Surprise Ending After Judge Orders Ship Seized Over Debts
description: The Crystal Symphony was set to arrive in Miami on Saturday, but it was diverted to the Bahamas after a U.S. judge ordered the ship seized over $4.6 million in unpaid fuel bills.
content: The Crystal Symphony left Miami on Jan. 8, as scheduled, on a two-week cruise. On the way back, things took an unexpected turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Manley
title: What Are the Essential Foods to Eat Where You Live?
description: Compile a list of the best local foods from your hometown.
content: If someone were to visit your hometown for a day, where would you send them to eat? What specific dishes would you recommend? What meals best represent your hometown’s people and culture? Why would you recommend these dishes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: How Did We Fail So Badly? Emily Oster and Ashish Jha on America’s Covid Response.
description: The two experts answer our questions about the pandemic.
content: With canceled plans, restaurants shuttering and talk of school shutdowns, the experience of the Covid pandemic can sometimes feel like two steps forward, one step back. And it’s not helped by changing (and sometimes confusing) guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the lack of key resources like at-home rapid tests, and the misinformation that abounds from Dr. Google.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Benedict Admits Being at Meeting About Priest Accused of Abuse
description: A statement by the former pope contradicted a previous statement to a law firm investigating allegations of child sex abuse by priests when he was an archbishop.
content: ROME — Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI said on Monday that he had been at a meeting at which the case of a priest accused of pedophilia had been discussed, contradicting a previous statement he made to a German law firm investigating accusations of clerical sexual abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Personal Profit in Congress
description: Some members of Congress have strangely good timing when it comes to stock investments.
content: In an academic paper published a few years ago, an economist named Serkan Karadas highlighted a suspicious pattern: Members of Congress earned higher than average returns on their stock investments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: After Shootings, Eric Adams Rushes to Release Safety Plan
description: Mayor Eric Adams, who won New Yorkers’ votes by campaigning on a need for improved public safety, is facing a growing crisis over gun violence.
content: Mayor Eric Adams rode to office on a platform of bringing down crime in New York City. In his first weeks as mayor, that challenge has risen to meet him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: 4 of the Best Veggie Burgers in Los Angeles
description: For classic plant-based burgers made with mushrooms, beets and the like, Tejal Rao recommends these restaurants.
content: So many veggie burgers available today are built with industrial meat substitutes that it’s hard to tell them all apart. The most delicious are still made with actual vegetables, and this is what makes them shine, giving them character, eccentricities and deep flavor. When a veggie burger is good, it’s a marvel of texture, often deepened with the umami of mushrooms, soy sauce, nutritional yeast, miso or kombu. Here are a few favorites in and around Los Angeles right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Cataract Surgery May Reduce Your Dementia Risk
description: Older adults who had cataract removal to restore their vision had a lower risk of Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
content: Surgery to remove cataracts, which cause the eye’s normally clear lens to become cloudy, can restore vision almost instantaneously. New research suggests cataract surgery may have another benefit as well: a reduced risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Sydney Ember
title: Omicron’s Economic Toll: Missing Workers, More Uncertainty and Higher Inflation (Maybe)
description: The latest wave of coronavirus cases is slowing the recovery, but its longer-term impact is less clear.
content: The Omicron wave of the coronavirus appears to be cresting in much of the country. But its economic disruptions have made a postpandemic normal ever more elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Past the Peak
description: New data points are emerging that may offer hope to exhausted Americans.
content: After weeks of skyrocketing case numbers, overwhelmed I.C.U.s and long lines at testing centers, new data points are emerging that may signal that the Omicron wave could finally be in retreat, offering some glimmers of hope to exhausted Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: How Kansas City and Buffalo Set a Record for Playoff Thrills
description: The teams combined to score 25 points in the last two minutes of the fourth quarter.
content: Kansas City and Buffalo combined to score 25 points in the last two minutes of the fourth quarter of their N.F.L. playoff showdown on Sunday night, a wild back-and-forth sequence that sent the game to overtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Charlie Savage
title: Julian Assange Can Appeal Decision to Extradite Him to U.S., U.K. Court Rules
description: The WikiLeaks founder has argued that American prison conditions would be harmful to his mental health. He faces a lengthy sentence if convicted on espionage charges.
content: LONDON — A British court ruled on Monday that the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange can appeal a decision that would allow for his extradition to the United States, where he would face charges under the Espionage Act in connection with obtaining and publishing secret government documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: The Best Brain Foods You’re Not Eating
description: For this week’s Eat Well Challenge, try some new foods that have been linked with improving your mood.
content: It’s time to start feeding your brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Frozen Citrus Desserts That Are Not Sorbet
description: Morgenstern’s has incorporated citrus into four new ice creams.
content: Nick Morgenstern has come up with a collection of irresistible citrus-based ice creams for winter. The rich flavors are nutty cardamom swirled with lemon jam; lemon curd-poppy seed ice cream, as a play on a popular poundcake flavor; moody dark chocolate olive oil ice cream bolstered with orange zest; and bright vegan lemon-lime, made with rice milk and coconut cream, with a texture that suggests sorbet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen to ‘Day X’
description: A five-part audio series that examines the rise of a new brand of extremism in Germany.
content: A German soldier, a faked Syrian identity and a loaded gun in an airport bathroom cracked the door open to a network of far-right extremists inside the German military and the police. It’s a story about a changing national identity — and the backlash against it — raising a question that democracies across the world are waking up to: What happens when the threat is coming from within?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: As Lia Thomas Swims, Debate About Transgender Athletes Swirls
description: And the rules could change for Thomas and other swimmers as the N.C.A.A. championships approach in March.
content: BOSTON — As Samantha Shelton, an accomplished Harvard swimmer, churned through the water in the 100-yard women’s freestyle on Saturday afternoon, the University of Pennsylvania’s Lia Thomas seemed content to sit on her hip in the adjacent lane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hitoshi Oshitani
title: What Japan Got Right About Covid-19
description: The country embraced the science of the coronavirus early.
content: It all began with the coronavirus outbreak on a Diamond Princess cruise ship back in February 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Troops Join Assault on Prison Where ISIS Holds Hostage Hundreds of Boys
description: The Islamic State seized a prison in Syria to try to free thousands of fellow jihadists and is using hundreds of imprisoned boys as human shields.
content: BAGHDAD — American ground forces have joined the fight to retake control of a prison in northeast Syria where Islamic State fighters are holding hundreds of boys hostage, the Pentagon said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: These Bubblies From Copenhagen Are Low A.B.V.
description: Copenhagen Sparkling Tea Company’s lineup of teas contain little to no alcohol and pair nicely with all manner of foods.
content: Complex blends of teas with herbal touches shape Copenhagen Sparkling Tea, a line of organic sparkling teas with little to no alcohol from Denmark, suitable to pour with dinner. They were created five years ago by a sommelier, Jacob Kocemba, and his business partner, Bo Sten Hansen, and are just now being sold in the United States. Gron, made with green and white teas and lemongrass with nice citrus notes and good acidity, is a standout in the collection; keep it in mind as you serve those long-life noodles for the Lunar New Year. It contains five percent alcohol, as does the Rod, pink, a bit sweeter and slightly tannic from the black tea in the mix. Alcohol-free Bla — made with jasmine, white and Darjeeling teas — is more delicate. The Lyserod, also alcohol-free, is rosy and fruitier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: ‘Here We Go’: Behind the Curtain With Soccer’s Prophet of the Deal
description: Fabrizio Romano has turned rumors into an industry. But is he an observer of soccer’s multibillion-dollar transfer market, or a participant in it?
content: The quickest way to capture the extent of the influence wielded by Fabrizio Romano, a 28-year-old Italian journalist with a five o’clock shadow and an overworked iPhone, is to boil it down into a list of easily digested numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Saad Hariri, Lebanon’s Former Prime Minister, Quits Politics
description: He was the leader of the country’s Sunni Muslims, one of the three main sects that share power, and the scion of a prominent political dynasty.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saad Hariri, a former prime minister of Lebanon and one of its most prominent politicians for nearly two decades, announced on Monday that he was suspending his political career amid a grave economic collapse that the country’s leaders have failed to stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Cash Aid to Poor Mothers Increases Brain Activity in Babies, Study Finds
description: The research could have policy implications as President Biden pushes to revive his proposal to expand the child tax credit.
content: WASHINGTON — A study that provided poor mothers with cash stipends for the first year of their children’s lives appears to have changed the babies’ brain activity in ways associated with stronger cognitive development, a finding with potential implications for safety net policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Kansas City wins in overtime with a Kelce touchdown catch.
description: In the fourth quarter, Kansas City and Buffalo scored a combined 25 points in the last two minutes.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Every sport needs a marquee rivalry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Eco-Leftists and the Far Right: Vaccine Mandate Forges Unlikely Coalition of Protesters in Germany
description: The prospect of a vaccine mandate has galvanized a nationwide protest movement attracting naturalists, neo-Nazis and ordinary citizens alike.
content: NUREMBERG, Germany — Maria Liebermann came wrapped in fairy lights and waved a peace flag featuring a white dove. Martin Schmidt carried a Germany flag with the word RESIST scrawled across it in capital letters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: baleful
description: This word has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Biden weighs a pivot on Ukraine.
content: President Biden is considering sending thousands of troops, warships and aircraft to the Baltics and Eastern Europe in response to Russia’s aggression toward Ukraine. The move would signal a major pivot for his administration, which until recently was taking a restrained stance on Ukraine, out of fear of provoking Russia into invading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Gem for Gluten-Free Croissants Moves to a Bigger Space
description: Noglu, on the Upper East Side, expands to a new ground-floor location with triple the seats in Carnegie Hill.
content: In Paris 10 years ago, Frédérique Jules founded Noglu, a gluten-free bakery and cafe. There are now three of them. In 2015 she opened a small New York storefront with a few seats on a sunny second floor in Carnegie Hill in partnership with Eli Zabar and also with the help of Mr. Zabar’s son Sasha Zabar. This week the New York spot is relocating several doors south to larger ground floor quarters with triple the number of seats, indoors and out. There’s a counter for prepared items; some sandwiches like croque monsieur are cooked to order. The menu has also expanded to include more breakfast items, lunch tartines, salads and vegetable dishes, but dinner is not an option yet. The mostly French-style Instagrammable breads and pastries — croissants, brioches, éclairs, tartlets, madeleines, scones and loaf cakes — are all made with gluten-free flours and starches like rice, chestnut, potato and corn; many do not betray their lack of gluten. Ms. Jules is keeping the original space as a production kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Michael Avenatti Trial Begins, Unearthing Artifacts of the Trump Era
description: Mr. Avenatti rose to prominence as one of former President Donald J. Trump’s primary foils. But prosecutors say he was defrauding his best-known client.
content: For much of 2018, the California-based lawyer Michael Avenatti and his client Stormy Daniels, a pornographic film actress, were key figures in the fervent political opposition to President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Orders Family Members of Embassy Staff to Leave Ukraine
description: The State Department warned that the United States would “not be in a position” to evacuate U.S. citizens should Russia invade.
content: WASHINGTON — The State Department said on Sunday that it had ordered family members of U.S. Embassy personnel in Kyiv, Ukraine, to leave the country amid increasing concerns about a possible Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
title: Threatened and Beaten, Afghan Women Defy Taliban With Protests
description: The Taliban have begun cracking down harder as women insist on their rights and as Western governments call for reforms.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — On a raw January morning, Khujasta Elham trudged through a snowstorm to sign her name on a government register.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: A Day of Divas
description: Two star sopranos, Renée Fleming and Sonya Yoncheva, held court in two of New York’s grandest venues on Sunday.
content: A little imperiousness? A lot of extravagance? A touch of the supernatural?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Is Tennis Moving Into a New Golden Age? We Can Only Hope.
description: It will be hard to let go of aging stars like Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams, and troubled ones like Novak Djokovic. But the time is coming, if it is not already here.
content: There was something for everyone. Roger Federer’s linen grace. Rafael Nadal’s punishing power. Novak Djokovic and his single-minded determination. The unwavering way Serena Williams dismantled tired tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden Would Like to Know What Your Problem Is
description: His marathon news conference last week did not suggest that he thought his presidency needed a reboot — or even a rebranding.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, that was one long presidential news conference last week. If Joe Biden wanted to show he has stamina, I guess he proved it. Otherwise, how did you think it went?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Old-Fashioned, Inefficient Light Bulbs Live On at the Nation’s Dollar Stores
description: A Trump administration weakening of climate rules has kept incandescent bulbs on store shelves, and research shows they’re concentrated in shops serving poorer areas.
content: For years, Deborah Turner bought her light bulbs at one of the many dollar stores that serve her neighborhood in Columbus, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Steve Schapiro, Photojournalist Who Bore Witness, Dies at 87
description: He documented the civil rights movement and subjects as diverse as narcotics users, migrant workers and movie stars, seeking to capture their emotional heart.
content: Steve Schapiro, a photojournalist and social documentarian who bore witness to some of the nation’s most significant political and cultural moments and movements, starting in the 1960s with the historic struggle for racial equality across the Jim Crow South, died on Jan. 15 at his home in Chicago. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 3 Firefighters Die After Being Trapped in Blaze at Vacant Baltimore Rowhouse
description: Part of the building collapsed as they battled the fire. Another firefighter was in critical condition and fighting for his life, officials said.
content: Three firefighters were killed on Monday and another was critically injured after part of a vacant Baltimore rowhouse collapsed, trapping them inside as they battled a blaze, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Amy Schneider Beats Matt Amodio’s Streak on ‘Jeopardy!’
description: Her winning streak is now second only to that of Ken Jennings, who racked up a 74-game run.
content: The category is: game-show legends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Why Unilever, Peloton and Kohl’s are attracting activist investors’ ire.
description: The companies are under pressure to generate bigger returns.
content: When a company’s stock starts to drag, activist investors often swoop in to shake things up, pressuring the laggard to cut costs, shed poorly performing assets or even consider selling itself altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Sony Music Buys Bob Dylan’s Recorded Music
description: The transaction for Dylan’s albums was made in July, about seven months after he made another deal — with Sony’s rival Universal Music — for his songwriting copyrights.
content: Sony Music has acquired the entire recorded music catalog of Bob Dylan, including all his previous albums and “the rights to multiple future releases,” the company announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Heavy Rains Weren’t Enough to Stop Winter Fires in California
description: The National Weather Service called the fast-moving blaze “surreal,” given the recent storms.
content: A fire in January? Californians have, tragically, seen that before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Mohammed Hadi
title: Wild Day for Stock Market as Investors Warily Await the Fed’s Moves
description: The S&P 500 slid into correction territory before rallying, and signals on Wall Street show that investors have become markedly more pessimistic.
content: A wave of panic-selling hit Wall Street on Monday, sending the market down as much as 4 percent before it bounced back and ended with a slight gain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Plush Side of Sour Cream
description: Vermont Creamery’s first sour creams are suitable for dipping in flavors like onion and chive or cilantro lime.
content: There’s seems to be renewed interest in sour cream, the kitchen staple from pre-yogurt times. And it’s caught the eye of some small dairy producers, including Vermont Creamery in Websterville, Vt. The dairy has just introduced an extra-rich cultured version, calling it “crème style.” There are three varieties: plain; a cilantro-lime that’s delicately tangy and suitable for Mexican-style dishes; and potato chip-ready fire-roasted onion and chive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Max
title: We Can’t Work It Out: Why I Finally Broke Up With the Beatles
description: Once I freed myself of  the Fab Four, it was as though I’d woken up from a deep sleep. I was suddenly available to a new musical world.
content: I know all the songs and so do you — I’ve known them all since I was a kid. But I not only know them all, I can play and sing them all — take your pick, from “Love Me Do” to “The End.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Helps Thwart Attack by Yemen Rebels on American Air Base in U.A.E.
description: The Houthi rebels fired two missiles at a base in Abu Dhabi where 2,000 Americans are stationed, the latest salvo in their escalating war with a Saudi-led coalition that includes the United Arab Emirates.
content: The U.S. military intervened on Monday to help the United Arab Emirates thwart a missile attack by rebels in Yemen on an air base where about 2,000 American personnel are stationed, U.S. and Emirati officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Police Culture on Trial in Case Against Officers in Killing of George Floyd
description: Derek Chauvin sits in a prison cell. The other three officers on the scene when George Floyd was murdered now face a trial of their own.
content: [Follow live coverage of the civil rights trial against three ex-police officers in the killing of George Floyd.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: A Newly Reported Gathering, and a New Headache for Johnson
description: The news came the same day as Mr. Johnson ordered an inquiry into a lawmaker’s claim of Islamophobia.
content: LONDON — His leadership already threatened by swirling claims of lockdown-breaking parties, Britain’s prime minister,  Boris Johnson, suffered a fresh blow on Monday when it emerged that a birthday celebration had been held for him while strict coronavirus restrictions were in force.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What is a stock market correction?
description: A sell-off pushed the S&P 500 to the cusp of a correction. The index recovered from the worst of its losses, but the decline signaled that investors had turned pessimistic about stocks.
content: After rising through much of the pandemic, the stock market has tumbled in recent weeks. On Monday, the sell-off pushed the S&P 500 stock index to the cusp of a correction, a Wall Street term for a significant decline from a recent high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: After Million-Mile Journey, James Webb Telescope Reaches Destination
description: The telescope’s safe arrival is a relief to scientists who plan to spend the next 10 or more years using it to study ancient galaxies.
content: After traveling nearly one million miles, the James Webb Space Telescope arrived at its new home on Monday. The spacecraft’s arrival checks off another tricky step as scientists on Earth prepare to spend at least a decade using the observatory to study distant light from the beginning of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: George Floyd’s Civil Rights Are Focus in Opening Arguments of Federal Trial
description: Three former Minneapolis police officers who were at the scene of Mr. Floyd’s death are accused of failing to intervene when they saw a fellow officer using excessive force.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — The most important piece of evidence used to convict Derek Chauvin of murder last year was a bystander video that showed the former Minneapolis police officer suffocating George Floyd with his knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: ‘In the End, You’re Treated Like a Spy,’ Says M.I.T. Scientist
description: Gang Chen was arrested a year ago on charges of hiding his links to China. The charges were dismissed, but he said the damage — to him, and to American science — has lingered.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When Gang Chen returned to his laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Friday, the day after the government had dismissed charges of lying on grant applications, he was surrounded by well-wishers, offering hugs and congratulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Recipes for Tet From Red Boat’s Founder
description: Cuong Pham, the founder of Red Boat fish sauce, has a new cookbook with recipes for the Lunar New Year, and more.
content: The Lunar New Year, called Tet in Vietnam, starts on Feb. 1. As for what to prepare, you might consider thit kho trung (extra special caramelized pork) or lil banh chung (rice cakes filled with pork, mung beans and shallots) from “The Red Boat Fish Sauce Cookbook,” which has a chapter about the holiday. There are many more satisfying but less elaborate recipes in this book by the founder of the excellent Red Boat fish sauce company, Cuong Pham — written with a food writer and a chef — including quick Red Boat bacon, shrimp and green beans; broccolini with garlic sauce; and chicken soup with cellophane noodles. Some dishes veer away from Vietnam, like pasta marinara, to showcase the versatility of fish sauce. (Chicken wings for a party crisped with a veneer of tapioca starch could fortify during halftime.) There’s also a full-dress rundown on homemade nuoc cham dipping sauces and a guide to ingredients. The story of Mr. Pham, his family and his essential condiment is woven throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Mallaby
title: What Elizabeth Holmes and Theranos Reveal About Venture Capitalism
description: Silicon Valley’s big investors are not like the rest of us.
content: The conviction this month of Elizabeth Holmes, founder of the fraudulent blood-testing start-up Theranos, has been presented as something grander: the discrediting of venture capital. Gullible investors poured almost $1 billion into Theranos, only to discover that it had all the substance of a B-movie prop. Coming on top of the venture crowd’s well-known offenses — sexism (women account for a shockingly low 16 percent of venture capital investment partners), racial bias (just 3 percent of partners are Black), and elitism (among V.C.s with M.B.A.s, one-third attended either Stanford or Harvard) — the apparent revelation that venture capitalists are incompetent feels like a knockout punch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: 8,500 Troops on ‘High Alert’
description: U.S. and NATO allies make plans in case of Russian military action.
content: U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has put 8,500 American troops on “high alert” for possible deployment to Eastern Europe, as NATO and the U.S. braced for a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Pentagon announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Lananh Nguyen
title: He Hurled a Smoothie and Insults. Now He’s Charged With a Hate Crime.
description: After his tirade was caught on video at a shop in Fairfield, Conn., James Iannazzo lost his job at Merrill Lynch. His lawyer said he was upset after his son had a severe allergic reaction to a drink.
content: The tirade started over a smoothie, with a Connecticut man demanding to know who made a drink that he said triggered his son’s severe allergic reaction to peanuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Supreme Court Will Hear Challenge to Affirmative Action at Harvard and U.N.C.
description: The court’s new conservative supermajority may be skeptical of admissions programs that take account of race to foster educational diversity.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina are lawful, raising serious doubts about the future of affirmative action in higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: The Strange Allure of the Blockchain
description: Why the appeal of cryptocurrencies and NFTs crosses borders of class and race.
content: My family managed to get together for a small Thanksgiving dinner last year. It was our first gathering since April 2020. After a big meal, my cousin only wanted to talk about one thing: cryptocurrency. He is a middle-aged Black man from New York, just a few years older than I am, but those years make a huge difference in his job security. When he came of age, he got a blue-collar job working for the city. He has worked at that job since he was 17 years old, so he will be able to retire as a relatively young man. And since the job is unionized, my cousin will retire with a pension and health benefits — the kind of pathway to economic security that is becoming increasingly rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Why Is Silicon Valley Still Waiting for the Next Big Thing?
description: The tech industry has grown ever more rich off big ideas that were developed more than a decade ago. New things like quantum computing and self-driving cars could take a while.
content: In the fall of 2019, Google told the world it had reached “quantum supremacy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marshall Heyman
title: Edmund White’s New Novel Is About a Husband’s Affair With Edmund White
description: Set in 2050, after its author has died, “A Previous Life” is a metafictional comedy about literature and sex.
content: A PREVIOUS LIFE Another Posthumous Novel By Edmund White
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Pithers
title: The Artists Behind the Ribbon-Filled Set of Loewe’s Men’s Show
description: Joe McShea and Edgar Mosa first caught the attention of Jonathan Anderson with their flag installations on Fire Island. Then they flew to Paris to make something new.
content: In the summer of 2020, when Americans were cautiously emerging from the first Covid-19 lockdown, the multimedia artists Joe McShea and Edgar Mosa quit New York City for Fire Island, a long strip of land just south of Long Island, and began making flags. McShea started out in photography while Mosa trained as a goldsmith, but the two, now partners in work and in life, have long been preoccupied with the interaction between fabric and the elements. In 2018, inspired by the Baroque frescoes at the 13th-century Palazzo Monti, in Brescia, Italy, where they were artists-in-residence, they developed a series of ephemeral sculptures by wrapping stone staircases in ribbons and photographing fabric in water. As an afterthought, they also created a flag made of ribbons fixed to a cardboard tube with masking tape. Though it was simple, they felt it had power and, sure enough, things took off two summers later, when the duo began sewing colorful hand-dyed silks, deadstock ribbons and tulle to lengths of ribbon that, doubled over, acted as halyards — or, as they refer to them, hoist ribbons — and tying those with simple bows to scavenged bamboo poles, which they planted on the beaches of Fire Island Pines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cooking for the Lunar New Year
description: Stir-fried noodles, nian gao and more recipes for the holiday.
content: Good morning. Planning for Lunar New Year, which falls this year on Feb. 1, begins in earnest this week, at least for those who are a) celebrating and b) won’t be doing so in a restaurant. Many will follow family traditions and eat what they usually do on the holiday — longevity noodles; dumplings; lumpia; steamed fish; tang yuan — cooking as much as possible in advance so that there can be a riot of dishes on the table when the moon does its thing, and to prevent chaos in the kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times
